sub_topic: Finding the derivative of a function
message_1:
Find the derivative of the following function:

f(x) = 3x^4 - 2x^3 + 5x^2 - 9x + 4

After finding the derivative, evaluate it at x = 2.
message_2:
To find the derivative of the function f(x) = 3x^4 - 2x^3 + 5x^2 - 9x + 4, we will apply the power rule, which states that the derivative of x^n is nx^(n-1).

f'(x) = d/dx(3x^4) - d/dx(2x^3) + d/dx(5x^2) - d/dx(9x) + d/dx(4)

f'(x) = 3(4x^3) - 2(3x^2) + 5(2x) - 9

f'(x) = 12x^3 - 6x^2 + 10x - 9

Now, we will evaluate the derivative at x = 2:

f'(2) = 12(2)^3 - 6(2)^2 + 10(2) - 9

f'(2) = 12(8) - 6(4) + 20 - 9

f'(2) = 96 - 24 + 20 - 9

f'(2) = 83

So, the derivative of the function f(x) at x = 2 is 83.
